data.title: Carl von Ossietzky University of Oldenburg in GERiT
data.meta_description: Carl von Ossietzky University of Oldenburg is a German research institution in Oldenburg. Further information can be found in GERiT, a DFG service.
data.text:
The University of Oldenburg was founded in 1973, making it one of Germany's young universities of applied sciences. The university's namesake is the Nobel Peace Laureate Carl von Ossietzky (1889–1938), who was one of the most prominent journalists of the Weimar Republic.

Open to new approaches – that is the crux of the University of Oldenburg's ethos. Adopting new approaches means researching and teaching future-focused topics, and practising interdisciplinarity, internationalism and social responsibility on a daily basis.

Core research areas

Academic staff at the University of Oldenburg conduct high-profile research in the key topics of:

Environment and sustainability:

biodiversity and marine science

sustainability

future energies

Humans and technology:

hearing research

cooperative critical systems

sensory neuroscience

healthcare systems and patient-centredness

Society and education:

diversity and participation

education and social participation

professionalisation processes in teacher education

social transformation and subjectivation

Supporting early career researchers is a high priority. Established university and non-university structures also enhance Oldenburg's status as a research location. These include the Helmholtz Institute for Functional Marine Biodiversity, a Max Planck independent junior research group and three Fraunhofer groups.
